sections.title: Risk Is Personal
sections.content: Two investors with identical portfolios can experience opposite emotions. Age, income stability, emergency savings, and temperament all shape how you perceive risk. Understanding these drivers keeps you from bailing out during inevitable downturns.

points.title: Capacity
points.description: How much loss you could recover from financially. Depends on time horizon, income, and savings.

points.title: Tolerance
points.description: Your emotional response to volatility. Some investors panic after a 5% drop while others stay calm through 25%.

points.title: Need
points.description: The return required to hit goals. Aggressive returns are unnecessary if your plan works with moderate growth.

sections.title: Volatility Snapshot
sections.content: A diversified 80/20 stock-bond mix historically experienced an average drawdown of 18% every 7 years. Planning for that swing keeps you invested.

sections.title: Translating Score to Strategy
sections.content: Use a simple scale: conservative, balanced, or growth-oriented. Conservative profiles lean on bonds and dividend stocks. Balanced investors split between broad-market equities and high-quality bonds. Growth profiles focus on equities and alternative assets with smaller bond buffers.

sections.title: Complete Your Assessment
steps: Rate yourself 1-5 on statements like 'I lose sleep when investments drop'. Sum the score.
Classify your score: 5-9 conservative, 10-15 balanced, 16-20 growth.
Draft a target allocation for your classification (for example, balanced = 60% stock funds, 35% bond funds, 5% cash).
Write one rule that keeps you from panic selling (e.g., 'wait 72 hours before trading after market drops').

sections.title: Automate Calm
sections.content: Enable automatic rebalancing or set calendar reminders to rebalance twice a year. Small adjustments keep risk aligned without emotional decisions.
